Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: A Student Centered Adaptive Learning Engine
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project represents a revolutionary advance in adaptive educational technology systems by using data collected from previous exercises to automatically generate hints and feedback for students. This work addresses the SBIR Educational Technologies and Applications subtopic EA5 - Learning and Assessment by making adaptive learning widely available and by providing tools to assess student performance in order to make interventions as early as possible and help students succeed. While it is well known that adaptive Computer Based Training (CBT) is more efficient and more effective, it has traditionally been cost prohibitive to produce in most domains. By leveraging the latest research in Big Data analytics and Educational Data Mining (EDM), this project will produce adaptive capabilities automatically, dramatically reducing the costs of producing more effective training and making such training widely available. The core customers for this technology will be providers of training systems. This includes publishing organizations, developers of software tools for education, and providers of corporate and government training. Institutions that are struggling to educate students, particularly across STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) fields, will be able to use this technology in their existing teaching systems and thus improve student engagement and performance.

The final outcome of this project will be an integrated set of software tools that collect data from existing computer/web based training software, and automatically generate adaptive capabilities to create a personalized learning environment for students. It does this by using novel EDM and machine learning techniques to build and organize student and problem models that improve over time as more data is collected. It also provides for the tracking of student progress on specific concepts or skills (knowledge tracing), allowing for easy assessment at any point in time. The system also dynamically selects the students' next problems to maximize student learning and minimize time needed to master a set of skills (problem selection). For complex multi-step problems, this system will provide context-specific, just-in-time hints to help students as they learn. The final product will include data adapters that allow developers of existing software to seamlessly connect with this system. Finally, a main differentiator of this system is the transparent process of data curation and the related visualization tools that expose the problem- and student-model generation process. This combination of human input and machine learning will provide researchers, developers, and educators tools to explore student data and allow for new insights into how students learn.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Overview

     TutorGen?s Student Centered Adaptive Learning Engine - (SCALE?) project centered around the development and validation of new machine learning techniques that automatically provide adaptive capabilities to any new or existing computer-based training product.  SCALE? is a back-end software system that connects seamlessly to existing educational technologies and, by using the novel algorithms we have developed, transforms a static, one-size-fits-all system into an adaptive and intelligent tutor.  SCALE creates this adaptivity based directly on the recorded experiences and interactions of students who have previously used the software. 

     The SCALE system provides a set of software tools that vastly decrease the high costs of developing true intelligent tutoring systems.  By providing adaptive capabilities automatically and in a cost-effective manner, SCALE enables more educational technologies to provide more personalized learning across a wider range of domains.  Adaptive, rather than static, instruction for students has been shown to be a highly effective way to improve student performance, as well as to deliver quality instruction in less time.  Yet currently very few developers take advantage of adaptive instruction, due to the historically high costs of creating adaptive content.  Our data-driven engine significantly reduces these costs, deriving intelligent tutoring capabilities from previously collected student data.  Further, unlike pure machine learning solutions, SCALE facilitates the contributions of human expertise, in both pedagogical and domain-specialized contexts, maximizing improvements and refinements over time.  The combination of human input with machine learning inherent in SCALE also has the potential to make important advances in our understanding of pedagogy and learner modeling. 

 

SCALE is not limited to a particular domain or market sector.  The SCALE engine can be connected to most edtech learning systems currently used in K-12 Education, Higher Education, and Corporate/Government Training.  Educational technology providers and content developers have significant investments in their current software.  SCALE allows this software to be reused without complete redevelopment, creating whole new markets for existing educational companies, and bringing intelligent tutors mainstream.  Companies and other organizations are constantly looking for teaching and training solutions that are flexible enough to meet varying learning needs and adapt to the preferences of users.  Thus SCALE will connect existing expertise and cutting-edge research with an innovative vision to expand the capabilities of intelligent tutoring systems, using our human-centered, data-driven approach.

Project Outcomes Summary

     The core technology of SCALE has been rigorously tested with data in academic settings from a variety of domains.  We conducted experiments that proved we could effectively create adaptive capabilities from data in multiple domains.  The technical methods and algorithms tested in our experiments validate the ability of SCALE to automate adaptive capabilities by using data.  By performing knowledge tracing and building skill and learner models, SCALE can perform adaptive problem selection and track student knowledge.  With an extended implementation of the Hint Factory, SCALE provides just-in-time hints for multi-step problems based on the best practices of successful students using the data already collected by the learning systems.  We completed a full build of the SCALE architecture that supports the following modules: data collector Adaptor; tutor engine to support cognitive and meta-cognitive factors; selector engine for problem and activity selection; and a variety of visualizations.  The SCALE dashboard offers visualization components including those to assist developers in validating content mastery by learners using their systems and the mapping of skills and knowledge components to problems.  SCALE also provides visualization components for teachers and administrators of SCALE-enabled educational systems to view learner progress and track student learning, both as a whole and individually.  These visualizations provide researchers, developers, and educators the tools to explore student data in ways that will allow for new insights into how students learn.  Full integration and load testing was completed.  And, pilot tests were conducted with actual learning systems demonstrating positive learning gains.

     SCALE also has expanded foundational components to support providing adaptive recommendations and a range of problem selection methods.  And, SCALE has the architectural infrastructure to support considering data-driven non-cognitive factors into the adaptive features to extend the capabilities.
